Why do you say "It seems the buy back means having to buy another Volkswagen"? The article does not say that people are getting a credit against the price of a new VW. Rather, it says that owners have the choice of getting their car fixed, or a buyback based on the pre-scandal KBB price. Curious as to whether you saw something elsewhere that says the buyback is really only a credit.

@Bob H
You say that the rest of us are commenting our of mass hysteria and that the pre-scandal value plus $5-10,000 is a good deal--so why “hyperventilation and the misconceptions?”

Let’s see. The original base MSRP for a 2010 Jetta Golf was $19,000 to $26,000. Pre-scandal Kelley Blue Book Price is ~$7,000 to $9,000.

VW is offering cash comp at $5,0000 to $10,000. This is one the lowest price models meaning the owner is looking at getting~ $5,000 comp. That’s a total of $12,000 to $14,000.

Tell me. What can I buy now with this total? I’m on a fixed social security income as a widow--my low 7 figure retirement is gone after the recession and my late husband’s decision to play high risk games ALONG with Wall Street with my retirement?

I wanted to have a car with low emissions. I thought I was getting it and was so happy when my emissions test turned out so well each year. Now I find out that those yearly tests were a scam as VW’s engineers figured out a way to criminally disguise those emission figures. Those engineers should be censored by their professional organization.

Now what can I buy for that money? The three “cheapest” 2016 all electric models are The Ford C, Prius, and Chevy Volt. Base MSRP is ~$26,000. I don’t have the $14,000 extra! That VW was going to be last car...and I live in an area with no public transportation--NOT my decision to end up here.

Maybe for you this seems like a “good deal,” IT’S NOT! I actually care deeply about our earth!

As an owner of one of the affected cars, I've been following the VW diesel scandal and I am seeing a lot of misconceptions and hyperventilation in these comments. Some perspective, please:

1. According to news accounts, including this one, the buyback is for the value of the car as it was before the scandal broke PLUS $5000 to $10,000, exact formula to be revealed tomorrow.

2. If an owner were to choose to get the emissions fixed instead, they get the car fixed and also get the $5000 to $10,000.

4. Yes, I too am very disappointed with VW and love to wring their necks, including jail time, but that’s going to be hard to do because we’ve already set a precedent that big business pays fines and the miscreants at the top walk. We haven’t jailed Wall Street bankers for bringing down the world’s economy, or GM for knowingly installing ignition switches that got people killed, so how can we now criminally prosecute VW managers and expect prison sentences?

5. Up to 40 times the amount of one type of pollution sounds like a lot but in the larger scheme of things these VW diesels are only about one in 500 of the passenger cars in the US. (255.8 million cars (Wikipedia) divided by less than 500,000 cheating diesels).

In sum, yes, VW has violated the law and betrayed its customers and dealers big time and needs to pay for it but mass hysteria is not called for.
I love my 2015 Passat TDI and would be happy to give it back in exchange for a new gas model and continue to pay the 25,000 at 0% interest I still owe.

Agree. There are far worse cars and trucks on the road. In many states, if a car is older than 15-20 years, an emissions test isn't required. Also, in some states (or areas), an emissions test isn't required at all regardless of the age of the car.

I didn't buy mine for the environmental claims. Nor for the gas mileage, because at the time I bought it, diesel was more than regular. I bought it because of the long commute and the engine. Drives better at 60,000 miles than when I bought it. Never had (still don't) any intentions of selling it. If the mpg goes down from 45 to 40 or 35, fine. I still plan on putting 250,000+ on the car and driving it cross country and back 3x over.

I just want it fixed and to move on.

I'm not one to count Google "hits", but casus BELLI (cause of bellicosity or war) is used often in writings about history, politics, and literature. So one might say that the abduction of Helen was the casus BELLI of the Trojan War. (I don't care whether it's proper Latin, because NYT is an English-language website!) An ironic feature of any supposed casus BELLI is that it is often an excuse for deploying military force rather than a cause. Remember the Maine, a ship that was not blown up by the Spanish except in the imaginations of people who wanted war.

As for EREBUS, the clue gave us two ways in. It's fairly standard for mythology to be the source of crossword entries. We also see the world's higher volcanoes often, as clues or as answers. That makes them good to know. The Maunas (LEA and Kea), Ararat, the nation where Kilimanjaro is found: Not only fair game but frequent. Solving puzzles in the Archives has been helpful to many Commenters; doing so can inform us of the variety of facts we might fruitfully explore. Moreover, EREBUS is on the storied Ross Island, familiar in geology, zoology, and the history of geographic exploration. It was explored by men traveling with the intrepid Sir Ernest Shackleton.

And although it's regretful, many of us have had DNFs on Mondays, Tuesdays, ... . Recent Tuesday puzzles have shown some resistance, for which I've repeatedly expressed gratitude.
Pretty hard for a Tuesday.  EREBUS crossing BELLI killed me.  Not familiar with either term. First DNF on a Tuesday in a long time.

My car did. I'm on my third. I paid 29k I July 2015. Put 9k down. Now, if I were to total it, I would just break even at 16k. That's well below the depreciation one normally sees in a year of low mileage use.

I don't want to offend VW diesel owners, but I don't entirely understand how they are entitled to such a large piece of compensation. Did the resale value of these vehicles really go down up to 10K? If so, why? In my mind, the victim in this extraordinary scandal is the American public (and the European public), related to the damage done to the environment from high emissions. And there should be a huge fine. I'm just not sure most of the fine should be paid to the owners, whose cars run just as good as they did all along.

[Sorry - first paragraph - 'your' mortgage, not you're mortgage.]

Since I'm still thinking about this, though, how about another back in the day mortgage story.

Years ago, my friend's father's father was killed relatively young in a tractor accident. This was when people had a little insurance to bury themselves, but not enough to replace a lifetime of income. Also, home values were much lower (as were incomes). Anyway, to help keep them in their home, the local bank who still held the mortgage (which was customary back in the day) allowed the widow (with two children) to make only interest payments for a few years (not reducing the principle), until such time as she was able to obtain full-time employment and get back on financial track. I don't think that would ever happen today.

Admittedly, local banks also had the power to make mischief. I'm sure they were responsible for aiding institutionalized segregation by disallowing mortgages for certain people in certain neighborhoods. We definitely wanted that practice to go down the drain. However, it's unfortunate we're now in the position of having thrown the empathetic community-building baby out with the bath water.

I think strengthening community banks, definitely while correcting their faults, would have made us better neighbors. It just seems when almost any company gets too big and too far removed from the community it serves, the product or service to the client becomes an afterthought. Think cable company.

If there is such a market to make vast sums of money in urban areas and lower income areas, the "Housing Advocates" should go purchase those properties and get rich. One issue with purchasing in the worst areas is the ability to get insurance. Another is the potential for crime.

After the crash, I purchased several properties in "blue collar" areas and have had no problem renting them out. Most of my tenants have bad credit. I am qualified to take section 8, but I typically rent my properties within a week of them becoming vacant and section 8 could never let me move somebody in that quick.
